title: Climate Change Indicators with Visuals
description: Key climate data and imagery from recent years, combining CO₂ trends, temperature anomalies, sea level rise, and extreme events.
narrative: From 2020 to 2024, the planet has seen continued rises in atmospheric CO₂, persistent global temperature anomalies, steady sea level rise, and increasingly damaging extreme events. The data and images together provide a stark illustration of the urgency of climate action.
key_findings: Atmospheric CO₂ rose from 414 ppm in 2020 to 423 ppm in 2024.
2022 showed a global average temperature anomaly of +1.1 °C.
Sea levels have risen over 95 mm compared to baseline, reflecting long-term global trends.
Wildfires in 2020 and deadly heatwaves in 2022 highlight the societal impacts of climate change.

images.label: Global Temperature Anomaly (2022) This data visualization shows the 2022 global surface temperature anomaly compared with the 1951-1980 average.
Global Wildfire Activity (2020) This still image shows the cumulative FRP over the year 2020, summing the 375 m resolution data into one-quarter degree bins, in a Robinson projection.

sources: NOAA  NESDIS  STAR Laboratory for Satellite Altimetry
